docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am relieved that the New Jersey State Supreme Court found the parental notification law unconstitutional (news article, Aug. 16), thereby protecting the reproductive freedom of young women like me. At first glance, the law may have seemed like a way for teenagers to involve their parents in important decisions, but it would have done just the opposite. There are many young women who do not want to tell their parents that they are pregnant because they suffer from abuse or incest. If forced to inform their parents before obtaining a legal abortion in New Jersey, they may have attempted self-induced abortions or left the state to terminate their pregnancies.
docs.abstract: Willa Laskowitz letter, commenting on August 16 article, praises New Jersey Supreme Court decision overturning as unconstitutional parent notification law requiring minors to inform parents that they are pregnant before getting legal abortion

docs.lead_paragraph: Mary Ellen Romary, the daughter of Darlene and O. Jules Romary of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., was married yesterday at the Boathouse in Central Park to Samuel N. Wender, the son of Dorothy and Norman Wender of Tamarac, Fla. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Louis L. Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part. Mrs. Wender, 31, is an advertising account manager for BabyTalk and Healthy Pregnancy magazines in New York. She graduated from Denison University. Her father retired as the vice president and secretary of the Union Carbide Corporation in Danbury, Conn.

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone; in August some galleries are open by appointment only. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show. Museums * ''THE ART OF WILLIAM EDMONDSON,'' Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, (212) 595-9533 (through Aug. 27). All creatures, celestial, human and animal, find their way into the limestone sculpture of Edmondson (1874-1951) and the results feel like an epic folk opera: score by Scott Joplin, libretto by Aesop, choreography by the great master dancers of Yorubaland. This exhibition also includes photographs of the artist by Edward Weston, Consuelo Kanaga and Louise Dahl-Wolfe showing him at home in Nashville where, at 59, he began to carve gravestones and garden ornaments for the local African-American community. In 1937 he made a solo debut at the Museum of Modern Art, and he has been part of the American pantheon ever since. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Holland Cotter).

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''A Trap of Welfare and Child Abuse,'' by Patrick T. Murphy (Op-Ed, Aug. 11): Teenage pregnancy remains a significant problem in this country, and according to Planned Parenthood, teenage pregnancy increased in New York City by 7 percent over the last four years. The reality is that welfare reform does not deter teenage pregnancy but that access to education, good health care and training in marketable job skills does.
docs.abstract: Monica Drinane letter comments on Patrick T Murphy's August 11 Op-Ed article, which said there has been decline in child abuse cases nationwide since passage of welfare reform law in 1996 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Al Gore has two big problems Bill Clinton and Al Gore. He may be able to finesse one of them -- Mr. Clinton. But the other he will have to face head-on.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column says Vice Pres Al Gore must deliver acceptance speech at Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles that clearly defines his vision for country and that overcomes widespread perception that Gov George W Bush is more likeable (M)
docs.snippet: Al Gore has two big problems  Bill Clinton and Al Gore.    He may be able to finesse one of them -- Mr. Clinton. But the other he will have to face head-on.

docs.lead_paragraph: Babies born even just a few weeks prematurely run a significantly higher risk of death in their first year, suggesting that inducing early labor is more dangerous than many obstetricians might think, researchers have found. A normal pregnancy lasts about 40 weeks, and babies born before 37 weeks are considered premature. The risks faced by very premature babies, those born before 32 weeks, are well documented. But over the past decade, doctors have begun using drugs to induce labor a few weeks early for convenience rather than health consideratons.

headline.main: Study Cites Health Risks to Preterm Babies

docs.abstract: New study finds that babies born even just a few weeks prematurely run significantly higher risk of death in their first year, suggesting that inducing early labor is more dangerous than many obstetricians believe; researchers are led by Dr Michael Kramer of McGill University (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Karenna Gore Schiff reached into her purse and pulled out a clump of typewritten pages. They were pockmarked by harsh X's through several paragraphs, dashes through words and arrows to the margins. ''It's a mess!'' she lamented. ''Here it is. It's like this, and I'm trying to figure out this, and I do it down here, and I cross out, and then I've got all this and I'm not sure if I should add this, and maybe it's too long, and I'm going this afternoon to type it up again and ask someone to look at it, whoever has time.''

headline.main: A Daughter Becomes a Valuable Adviser

docs.abstract: Karenna Gore Schiff, Al Gore's 27-year-old daughter and close political adviser, is writing her own speech introducing roll call that will formally nominate him for President; photo with her sister, Kristen, at convention event in Los Angeles (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Abby Bernstein feels as if she has been told that she has just about every ailment in the book. Over the past 12 years, dozens of medical specialists have informed her that she has the flu, drug allergies, mononucleosis, Epstein-Barr virus, a gallbladder problem and even food poisoning. And, of course, she has been told several times that she has absolutely nothing, despite chronic bouts of nausea, fever, fatigue, skin lesions and swelling in nearly every joint in her body, including her jaws.

headline.main: Baffling Disorders Often Stem From Immune System Failure

docs.abstract: Article explains effects of autoimmune disorders that afflict estimated 14 million Americans, causing wide variety of ailments that often defy diagnosis and treatment; several patients describe bouts with baffling disorders; photos of Abby Bernstein and Catharine and Laura Shaner (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's speech to the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. Isn't it great to be here in California together? Forty years ago, the great city of Los Angeles launched John Kennedy and the New Frontier. Now, Los Angeles is launching the first president of the new century: Al Gore.

headline.main: Clinton's Address to Party: Extolling 8 Years of Change in America
